posts.name: Jonah Thiele
posts.cooked:
Our team has spent the past 2 days working on auto code to merely drive forward and we are having issues with some erratic behavior in our drive for distance command. The issue is our subsystem case sometimes will pass the value to the drive motors in the while case and after a redeploy a default zero will be pasted instead. We probed the values, and they continue to update, but the invalid value of zero is still passed to the motors, when the code in the case structure is outputting a value of 0.15. The calculations are mostly correct, but the main issue with our vi is the erratic passing of data.

This is the code of the drive controller vi 20230311_163349 1920×2560 266 KB 20230311_163636 1920×2560 232 KB

20230311_163349 1920×2560 266 KB

20230311_163349 1920×2560 266 KB

20230311_163636 1920×2560 232 KB

20230311_163636 1920×2560 232 KB

this is the values we where getting during our testing 20230311_163603 1920×2560 297 KB 20230311_163631 1920×2560 252 KB

20230311_163603 1920×2560 297 KB

20230311_163603 1920×2560 297 KB

20230311_163631 1920×2560 252 KB

20230311_163631 1920×2560 252 KB

Sorry in advance for the low quality pictures.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Correct me if I am wrong, but your entire block of code is in a case structure.

So, if the case is true, your values will be calculated.

When it goes false, you still see those calculated values in the probe window - but your false case may be passing through zeroes.

My point here is - you need to make sure your case structure is staying in the right state.

That would be my initial guess.  it’s usually better if you include a zipped up version of your code so people can dig in.

posts.name: Jonah Thiele
posts.cooked: The case structure is part of the subsystems paradigm for frc which our team uses. The case structure is the current command. The problem is if it was running a different case or command the update times would be different, but the probes show that the code inside and outside the case is running at the same time.

posts.name: Jonah Thiele
posts.cooked: The code can be found on bit bucket here: Bitbucket

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Cool.  I’m grabbing it now.  I’ll take a timeout from work to look at it.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I don’t see anything that jumps out immediately.  However, it’s impossible for those wires to change the values from a number to a zero spontaneously (or else we’d see a whole slew of labview developers complaining).  I’d create an array that stores the values each loop of your “current command” and the value you are probing.  Often, loops happen too fast for you to see in the probe window, and storing the data adds another hint as to what the problem might be.

posts.name: Jonah Thiele
posts.cooked: we checked the array, the command is only running once. we replaced the stop flag with a false constant and set the wait time to -1. The command only appears to be running only once however after these changes.

posts.name: Ajay
posts.cooked: Are you still looking for the support?

posts.name: Jonah Thiele
posts.cooked: We finished our competition. we ended up giving up on the command and control structure and just re-wrote the code in Tele-op. It worked fine for the competition.

posts.name: JeffB
posts.cooked:
I’m not at a PC with that code on it currently.  I’ll describe what I think the issue is and you can dig around at some point when you’re with your robot.

In the support code for the subsystem, there are some VIs that are created.  In one of them, there’s an enum constant that passes the state of your system to the robot.  Instead of a default that says “use the last value” a lot of subsystems get created with one that says “send a zero”  I can’t remember the exact names off the top of my head (reserve or something to that effect?)

If you change that default setting and save the VI, I expect you’ll stop seeing this behavior.  It sounds like you’re getting that back and forth behavior instead of a steady flow you expect and I’m 95% sure that’s the issue you’re running into.
